Automation does not imply lack of human involvement - perhaps "full
automation" does. But we never used that term.

The most effective and common form of automation is one in which the
machine (or computer) and the human each perform the tasks that they
do best or more effectively.

Unless it's misused, automation is a good thing - a VERY good thing.

The first benefit of automation is that it frees human beings from
performing aspects of a given task that don't require their
intelligence, creativity, and insight and allows them to focus on the
aspects that do.

A second benefit of automation is that it allows you to do things that
would be impossible or impractical to do manually and allows human
beings to reach well beyond what they could do on their own. Some
people call this IA (Intelligence Amplification).

We designed Agitator to automate the aspects of testing that would
benefit from automation and, VERY intentionally, did NOT automate the
parts that REQUIRE human intelligence, creativity, and understanding
to have any meaning (e.g. the creation of test assertions).

Different people prefer different levels of automation for different
tasks (e.g. my mother still likes to make home-made fettuccine without
a pasta maker - mixing them and cutting them by hand. Enjoying the
process and liking the fact that each strand is a little different.
Takes ~2hrs though. Other use a Cuisinart and a pasta machine. Others
buy them at Safeway :-)).

When it comes to testing, including test creation, my belief and
experience is that the *right* *level* of automation is not only
acceptable and desirable, but necessary.

Alberto
